patient_information: 30-year-old male Chinese itinerant trader with no reported comorbidities or immunosuppression. No vaccination or allergy information stated.
chief_complaint: Fever, chills, headache, and dry cough for 7 days.
history_of_present_illness: The patient developed slide-positive falciparum malaria while living in southern Laos and was treated with intravenous infusions and intramuscular artemether 80 mg for 5 days, brought from China as standby therapy, but did not improve. Fever persisted, jaundice developed, leading to transfer to Vientiane.
exposure_and_epidemiology: Residing and trading in southern Laos, an area with reported artemisinin-resistant malaria. No specific animal, water/food risks, or sick contacts mentioned.
vitals: Febrile at 39.5°C (103.1°F), normal blood pressure, normal Glasgow Coma Score.
physical_exam: Nausea, dry cough, moderate dehydration, chest pain, abdominal tenderness. Chest clear, no hepatosplenomegaly detected.
labs_and_diagnostics: Giemsa smear negative for malaria parasites, rapid diagnostic test (HRP-2) positive for Plasmodium falciparum. Serum creatinine and glucose normal. ALT 301 U/L, AST 230 U/L, ALP 470 U/L, total bilirubin 14 μmol/L, direct bilirubin 6.4 μmol/L. Blood culture grew Salmonella typhi. Chest radiograph normal.
differential_diagnosis: Bacterial co-infection with Salmonella species due to persistent fever post-malaria treatment. Artemisinin-resistant falciparum malaria considered due to regional prevalence and poor response. Other infections like scrub typhus, murine typhus, leptospirosis, tuberculosis, or dengue fever possible in Laos. Substandard artemether or dosing issues also considered.
management_and_clinical_course: Admitted, re-treated with artesunate IV for possible resistant malaria, and started ceftriaxone for suspected typhoid fever. Blood culture confirmed Salmonella typhi. Fever resolved after 5 days, discharged on oral ciprofloxacin for 7 days. Follow-up showed full recovery.
final_diagnosis: Typhoid fever caused by Salmonella typhi, confirmed by positive blood culture, with initial misdiagnosis as resistant malaria. The diagnosis fits persistent fever and abdominal tenderness post-artemether, with malaria ruled out by negative smear and response to antibiotics.
